726098f-b.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726098f-b.text:
Astoria Park (lueens): the band shells at the southern end of
the park, seen fromm 19th Street and Hoyt Avenue. The Triborough
Bridge was la ter erected here, just to the right of the shell. View
2 was taken from the bridge looking west across Hell Gate toward
Manhattan. View 3 shows the Astoria Park swimming pool, viewing in-
land from the bridge. 9n the lw ft is the Hell Gate railroad bridge.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: March 14, 1931
NO PEPRODUCTIONS  Views 2,3: July 25, 1936

726101f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726101f-a.text:
Astoria Park:
Twenty-sixth Ave., (foreground, not shown) north side, between
East River (left) and 2nd Street (right), showing in the background
the Hellgate Lighthouse and the field house of the Astoria Athletic
Field. Fort Stevens formerly occupied this site.
1922.
Eugene L. Ambruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

726100f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726100f-a.text:
(1)
Astoria Park, showing a small cottage opposite 24th Road in the
Park. The Mallison Silk Mills at the left,face Twenty-fourth Ave.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, from another angle showing also the Hell Gate Bridge in
the background.
March 144, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

726099f-a.title: Queens: Astoria Park.
726099f-a.text:
Astoria Park (2ueens): Scenes of the Park on the East River
shore. Note, in view 1, a portion of the steel structure of the
Triborough Bridge under construction. View 2 shows kids playing
on a mound while the park is being improved. View 3 shows an an-
cient house, one nf the remaining few homes from the time when
this area was a fashionable residential district, and gas tanks.
P. L. Sperr  View 1 Sept. 20, 1934
NO REPRODUDTIONS  View 2: November 9, 1935
View 3: July 10, 1937
